title: Reportback from Lützerath – Earth First! Journal

last_post.content:
"Lützerath is the latest of dozens of villages that have been evicted, inhabitants dispossessed under old Nazi legislation, to facilitate the expansion of lignite coal mines, the dirtiest and most carbon intensive form of electricity generation. This eviction takes place three years after the eviction of the neighbouring Hambacher Forest in 2018, which lasted over four weeks and led to the death of a young film maker. The eviction was stopped by the courts in October 2018, and later declared illegal.

The fight against coal is not over. It’s 11pm, dozens are people have been hospitalised, one person still unconscious. A medic recounts: “What I experienced today was beyond my imagination. I’ve seen every bone in the human body broken today”.

But thousands of people are still there, blockading and occupying space. Tomorrow, more people will once again make their way to the mining area. Lützerath has shown the ecocidal determination of fossil capital and the state, but it has also been a powerful symbol of resistance. Using a diversity of tactics, people from different backgrounds have come to together to show how their determination to fight back is even greater. People will keep resisting in whatever way they can. Join them."

#Lutzerath #RWE #EarthFirst #Ecocide #Coal #Germany

Via @earthfirst

https://earthfirstjournal.news/2023/01/15/reportback-from-lutzerath/

title: Mrs. Frisby and the Rats of Nimh

last_post.content:
Mrs. Frisby & the Rats of NIMH has such an efficient, accomplished start. Chapter one grounds a clear place and broadly familiar relationships, creates interest with appropriately mousy details, roughly sketches out the surrounding area, hints at the backstory, establishes a problem that's comprehensible to kids and compelling to parents, foreshadows the larger dilemma, and ends just a bit mysteriously. Just a model first chapter in nearly every way. #kidsLit #theLibrary
https://www.simonandschuster.com/books/Mrs-Frisby-and-the-Rats-of-Nimh/Robert-C-OBrien/9781534455733

Is academia facing a massive burnout crisis?

Academics are increasingly "reevaluating whether their jobs are worth the high cost to their personal well-being. They are less willing to continue in positions with oversized workloads, salaries that do not keep up with inflation, and inflexible policies."

48% of universities report that faculty turnover increased in 2022 and >70% of academics reported mental health difficulties in 2021

Retraites : une réforme libérale, chronique de Clément Viktorovitch, qui revient sur deux conceptions opposées de la retraite : le salaire différé (ce qu'elle devient au fil des réformes) vs le salaire continué (comment elle a été pensée initialement) :

title: Splitting the atomic scientists: how the Ukraine war ruined physics

last_post.content:
I hadn't heard of this, but the Large Hadron Collider collaborations have not published since March 2022 because of a disagreement about whether to list Russian collaborators on papers: https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/jan/15/scientists-ukraine-war-cern-physics-large-hadron-collider

Regardless of whether you think this is right or wrong, imagine any event that would cause your subfield to stop publishing. You would lack the coordination to pull anything like this off.

HT @Samuelmoore

#Oxfam #Davos #inegalités

Le soutien public pendant la pandémie a permis d’éviter une grave crise économique mais il a aussi conduit à l’enrichissement des plus riches, sur une tendance déjà forte : il est plus que temps de partager.

title: DOWN WITH THE (design) SYSTEM! - Radical UX - Medium

last_post.content:
So, this piece is making the rounds, and it’s been echoed approvingly by some big names in the tech world, but I have some complicated misgivings about its fundamental conclusion: that design systems were a necessary crutch as web ux evolved, but they’ve become a straight jacket keeping us from true user-focused experience.

https://medium.com/radical-ux/down-with-the-design-system-f0d3c6a74649

Ever wondered about pandoc's version numbers? Pandoc follows the “Package Versioning Policy”, a convention used in the Haskell ecosystem. The version number components are EPOCH.MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH; bumps in the major version happen when there are API changes in the Haskell library.
https://pvp.haskell.org/

Current changes in the dev version justify a new "epoch", so the next version will be pandoc 3.0 (to be released soon)!

title: Richest 1% bag two-thirds of $42 trillion in new wealth: Oxfam

last_post.content:
Richest 1% bag two-thirds of $42 trillion in new wealth: Oxfam https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2023/1/16/richest-1-percent-bag-two-thirds-of-42-trillion-in-new-wealth-oxfam

'The world’s top 1 percent grabbed nearly two-thirds of the $42 trillion in new wealth created since 2020, Oxfam says in a new report released to coincide with the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

The share was almost twice as much money as the amount obtained by the bottom 99 percent of the world’s population, according to Oxfam’s “Survival of the Richest” report released on Monday.

Billionaire fortunes are increasing by $2.7bn a day, while at least 1.7 billion workers now live in countries where inflation is outpacing wages, the report said.

At the same time, half of the world’s billionaires live in countries with no inheritance tax for direct descendants, Oxfam said, putting them on track to pass on $5 trillion to their heirs, more than the gross domestic product (GDP) of Africa.'

#capitalism #austerity #greed #death #ClassWar #davos

This is fascinating! The Braille Institute has developed a font - free to download - that's designed to be clearer for readers with lower vision.

An example of one of the aspects of low legibility that they tackled attached.

It's named Atkinson Hyperlegible. Atkinson was the Institute's founder - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Robert_Atkinson

Here's where you can read about the font and download it: https://brailleinstitute.org/freefont

#Accessibility

Have read it, and the book is really quite excellent. At turns whimsical and hard-hitting.

Big ideas conveyed through very human and humane narrative.

And the soul of the book is the best, most adorable, most big-hearted moose you will ever meet.

Whistle is the G.M.O.A.T. (Greatest Moose Of All Time).

Almost certainly one of my top picks for 2023.

Full review to come.

title: Stop using the elbow criterion for k-means and how to choose the number of clusters instead

last_post.content:
How do you choose the number of clusters in k-means clustering? More generally, how do you choose the number of additive components in your mixture model? Don't use the elbow criteria. Instead use the variance ratio criteria, Bayesian information criteria, or the gap between the sum of squared errors.
#MachineLearning
https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12189

By now, many of you have seen the footage of the monk (or mud wizard) facing off with hapless riot police during the defense of #Lutzerath this past weekend.

If you have not seen it, treat yourself to it now:

https://twitter.com/HerrHoert/status/1614386528934846470

In fact, this mysterious figure already appeared in 2018, during the defense of the ZAD (the "Zone to Defend," a longtime squatted area where the residents blocked the construction of an airport) at Notre-Dame-des-Landes.

According to le Monde, the police ambushed the monk among a group of other defenders. The monk threw three buckets of water at the police, proclaiming "I baptize you in the name of the ZAD!" In the ensuing chaos, he made off with one of their batons.

To learn more about the #ZAD:

https://crimethinc.com/ZAD

Victory to the mud wizards! Defend the earth!

I gave Hofstadter's MU puzzle¹ to #ChatGPT to see how quickly its ability to reason fell apart. I hoped this would show something interesting about its robustness at the syntactic level of symbols versus on the semantic level of meaning. I changed "M", "I", and "U" to "A", "B", and "C", respectively, just in case that helped thwart popular training data. The results were disappointing: it failed at the syntactic level, violating string state, puzzle rules, or both.

¹ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MU_puzzle

title: Design can be free – Scott Jenson

last_post.content:
My post on better smart device design is a first in a series. I tackled the easy case first: presentation. It's an obvious place to start. The next step is to discuss better hardware (e.g. dials vs buttons) but it's tricky as it's so hard to justify the extra cost. Likely a small crowd but I'm trying to find any stories from #UXDesign folk on trade-offs or stories trying to better devices.

Are you a fan of #OverpassTurbo for #OpenStreetMap data mining and visualization?

If you are, you just might find #OverpassUltra interesting and very promising: https://overpass-ultra.trailsta.sh

Fueled by #MapLibreGLJS, it is definitely faster, and
can work with much larger areas compared to the original.

It also features "live mode" , that lets you query data while you pan & zoom, rather than re-running your query.

Its developer, Daniel Schep describes it as a reimagined Overpass Turbo.
Signups on takahe.social are now open until we hit 100 users! If you'd like an account, head to https://takahe.social/auth/signup/

title: How Finland Is Teaching a Generation to Spot Misinformation

last_post.content:
Finland has closely watched the Russian troll factory's efforts to create chaos in free democracies. We now educate our children to recognize #misinformation and rank #1 in our ability to resist it.

I wish the Americans would do the same.

title: spear thrower; portable art | British Museum

last_post.content:
Around 15,000 years ago, this mammoth-shaped spear thrower was carved from reindeer antler. The handle (between the tusks) was broken in antiquity. Discovered in 1866 by Peccadeau de l'Isle, in the Montastruc rock shelter, France. Magdalenian period. 📷 my own.

Read more: https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/H_Palart-551

#Archaeology
#Art
Improvisation 9, 1910 #abstractart #vasilykandinsky https://www.wikiart.org/en/wassily-kandinsky/improvisation-9-1910

title: A dozen years of Chinese wind, solar and nuclear generation show clear scalability winners

last_post.content:
> In 2014, I made the strong assertion that China’s track record on #wind and #nuclear generation deployments showed clearly that wind #energy was more scalable than nuclear. title: Ants Live 10 Times Longer by Altering Their Insulin Responses | Quanta Magazine

last_post.content:
This is fascinating - Tapeworms eaten by Acorn #ants secrete more insulin that seems to aid in the ants #longevity. They want the ants to live as long as possible, to increase their chances of being eaten by a #woodpecker 😳.
